newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian meat not hit by Iraq freeze.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian meat not hit by Iraq freeze.

text.p: Australian meat exports would not be affected by the suspension of the proposed United Nations' oil-for-food deal, said Australian Meat and Livestock Corp (AMLC) manager, international sheepmeat and livestock marketing Lloyd Beeby.
The AMLC, an Australian meat industry statutory authority, had explored the potential to export meat to Iraq under the UN oil-for-food resolution, Beeby told Reuters.
But it was discovered that meat was not on Iraq's priority list. A fair amount of meat was selling at Iraq's roadside butchers, he said.
"It was fairly evident that at (present prices) we would be hard-pressed to even better it," he said.
"We've come away having made all of the contacts, ready to move at a moment's notice, but without any orders or any sign of any orders.
"From what's happening there at the moment, we're not affected at all," he said.
This did not mean that Iraq's market would not improve in future, he said.
Much of Australia's problem was European export subsidies, which left Australia uncompetitive at present rates, he said.
Iraq was not a large consistent market for Australian meat before the Gulf War, although Australia had exported "helpful" amounts to Iraq in particular years, he said.
Iraq's oil-for-food deal, suspended on Tuesday after the U.S. missile attack on Iraq, would have allowed Iraq to sell US$2 billion worth of oil every six months to buy food and medicine.
Alistair Nicholas of the Australian Trade Commission (Austrade) told Reuters that the effect on Australian exports to Iraq would be negligible because no oil-for-food deals had gone through.
"But it is a further delay to any opportunities coming to fruition," he said.
